data.text: John Steinbeck tells a true story of his friend, Doc, who was hiking across the state for the fun of it. When Doc explained to people he was hiking for the fun of it, they treated him with suspicion, and wouldn't let him stay on their property. After a while, Doc started telling people he was hiking across the state, and people treated him differently. They offered him food, places to stay, so much more when they thought he had a purpose to what he was doing. Sometimes people find it strange that a person should carry out an act, that is enjoyable in itself. They want to have a reason, it is a foreign idea that people should want to just ride a bike for the sake of riding a bike. Keep riding, tell people you do it because you like riding, and hopefully it convince more people to ride, and to share in the enjoyment of it. Excuse the length.

data.text: I understand the cynicism, but not everyone riding for charity has a main purpose of funding their travel. Because fund raisers can legally use some of the money they raiser to pay reasonable expenses in support of their charity efforts. Although I do get the feeling this is becoming more common nowadays, a bit like social media influencers doing something to just blag goods or services. If that is what you mean by a scam. That is one reason I would not ride for charity. I would not like to get labelled and don't agree with the motives. There seem to be two main types of charity travellers. There are those who have some strong connection with the charity they are raising money for, one that they strongly believe in and have probably supported in other ways in the past, with no benefit to themselves. Then there are those who seek out a random charity to raise money for, seeking some benefits in return.
